A wooden-planked dining room with a large bar, and a lot of tables, plus outside seating under a trellace.  The service is upbeat and friendly (probably the only  thing they missed in trying to copy New England tradition.)  While I'm not sure the chowdah recipe is traditional, it sure was delicious and gets a top rating from me.
author: Ken B.

description: I want like this place  because it is in my hood but everytime I go there I am sooo let down! The service is really bad and why are the people that work there just a little off. Not off in the good way either. The last time we were there the waitress treated us like she was an ex that we jilted. The service is slow and they are always confused. Not a good place for people with children because they seem to hate them. The breakfast is awful. They give you the  crispified bacon they use for BLT's with your eggs. If you like people who are full of hate then this might be your cup of tea. The french fries are declicious other than that where is the charm?
author: Tiffany M.

description:
the french fries i can eat forever.  where can i find these so i can make them at home? 

service is cool for a bar. i dont reallty undestand bar/resturants in general... i usually go for the food and drink at the same time.. but i guess its nice to have a bar.. where i can get drunk and eat my BAC away

if i could change 3 things about the Connecticut Yankee it would be... 
1.  better chicken tender. worst chicken tenders ever.  
2.  a healthy pour. 
3.  booth seating.
author: Doug ..

description: A Ketel martini up with a twist to go along with my Barry Bonds beans and my half a BLT--now that is a great lunch; it also goes well with the professional ping pong games that are always on during the day. Great neighborhood bar and a great place for a beer after a spin class at World Gym.
author: Deborah S.

description: Used to come here a lot for lunch when I worked in the area.  Pretty average bar food.  Fish and chips, burger and fries, etc.  Now that I live around here, I'm definitely here more often.  The service is better around lunch/weekend brunch than it is around dinner.  One time at dinner, we had to actually get up from our seat and find the server to ask her if we could order dessert.  Their brunch specials are better and are worth coming back for on the weekends.  That and you can sit outside and enjoy a sunny day in Potrero HIll.
author: Jean A.

description: Terrible service.... I don't know if we hit a bad day or something... The waitress there seems new, she didn't know what's going on... When we ordered a drink, she thought it was food.. until I had to hold up the menu and pointed it to her.   It took forever for her to get our food order, then it took forever for the food to arrive.  Everything tasted mediocre, nothing was good enough.  I guess I can't expect much from bar food.... But at least can I get some good service?  Drinks came out pretty fast, other than that, everything else was thumb down.
author: Lily K.

description:
I'm a Boston transplant in the Bay Area and have been told on multiple occasions to visit the Connecticut Yankee. "It's the Sonny McLean's of San fran", I was told. 

I ventured across the bridge (I live in Oakland)  on a day I knew the Bruins and Celtics would be playing at the same time (both playoff games) and found the dive bar hidden a block off the beaten path, which i actually liked. The blue awning with the red "Red Sox font" lettering outside the front door was inviting. 

When i walked in it was less than 30 minutes before the start of the Celtics' and Bruins' games so, having visited Sonny McLean's in Santa Monica on a similar type day last year, I expected a slew of Green and yellow jerseys, at least based on what I've read and heard. Instead, there were 4 people in the entire bar (I didn't look onto the back patio), including the bartender, who was dressed in one of those SF Giants' Hawaiian shirts. 

He was an angry old man, who seemed to hate all Boston based sports' fans, even though I was under the impression that they were the bar's "target market". The walls did have a bunch of Boston based newspaper articles, but they also had a Terrell Owens' Philadelphia Eagles' jersey and a Vikings helmet hung up as well. 

It was slightly confusing to someone who had been told by various sources that this was supposed to be a Boston transplant's "bar away from home". To kick it off, they didn't even show the Bruins/Canadians game, tuning into the Rangers/Capitals game instead. When I asked about it the bartender replied with, "what you see is what you get, we ain't got no hockey package - it's baseball season."

Now, the place, w/o the idea that it was supposed to be a targeted toward Boston transplants, seems like an awesome dive bar. The atmosphere, the comfort, and the beer - all great. Hole in the wall, of the beaten path, dirty, and old - all great attributes for the perfect dive bar in my opinion. The issue was that it's being marketed as, whether the bar owner is trying to or not, as a Boston transplant bar and it's a far cry from such, at least based on my one visit. Hell, throughout the first half of the Celtics/Bulls game only two fans walked in. 

The meatball sub was great though, highly recommend it if you need to visit the place for yourself. Just don't go in with the expectations of being greeted with open arms as a Boston transplant. If anyone knows of such a place in the Bay area I'd love to hear about it.
author: Adam H.

description: I liked this bar.  My group had a room all the way in the back to watch the game.  My vegetarian chili was not amazing, but respectable.  The waitress was good with getting the orders.  Nice job, well-done.
author: Joanna S.

description:
Best french fries you'll ever eat.

But the service BLOWS.

Every time I bring people in there to sample the good food (fries, calamari, burgers, buffalo wings, and philly cheesesteaks) we get totally written off by the wait staff. I gotta admit the red headed guy is okay.

One time we went in there during the world series and they were watching the presidential debate on all the TV's. They wouldn't change the channel on a single one. 

But the food always brings me back.
author: Paul w.

description: The staff is great and the food excellent, albeit a little pricey. The heated back patio is great, I'm a fan.
author: Ziad E.

description:
I didn't really care about the sport stuff on the wall. I know others would but I wasn't really looking that much. I watched some basketball game on their tvs. There are many of them placed strategically for viewability.
We had the wings and fries both were good but average. 
It was a Wednesday (late) afternoon before Thanksgiving so it was pretty empty and our waitress was bored but attentive. The crowd I was with had many drinks (beers from the tap and whiskey or something like that) she kept their glasses full. She also kept my glass full when I stopped drinking beer and ordered a water, which I appreciated.
Then when our table asked for the tab she brought everyone water, which was a nice touch.
It was night time and had been raining so we didn't sit outside on the patio but we went out to smoke and it was nice. View of the stars, some plants...
It's not the best but its cool to go and just relax with a few drinks and a few laughs.
Plenty of parking. Oh and you can see the freeway from the front so you can tell if the traffic has died down or not before you go home.
author: Edi B.

description: For some reason I've been hanging out in Portreo Hill a lot lately, and it's been really nice coming in contact with different slices of the SF population in some of the neighborhood's staple haunts. The Connecticut Yankee is an awesome hangout joint-lots of draft and bottled beers, spacious patio seating, and live music. I noticed on the menu there's a prime rib dinner for $18.95; I'm not too sure I want to try it, but I might try something else greasy on the menu. There isn't a whole lot else to write about, but I've always had an enjoyable time here so it is what you make it.
author: Linda L.

description: Ive been here a couple of times when Ive been in the Potrero Hill area. The food is a good value, and tasty, but the establishment is not as nice as it could be. The outside seating is made of worn/splintered wooden benches and the paint is peeling off the side of the building. The "San Francisco run down" look is really wearing thin. Anyway, we got or food right away, which is usual for them. However, at one point the waitress spilled a glass on me, it was empty and i saw it coming, so I had time to deflect it. ALSO my partner's order was wrong. On top of which it took 25 minutes to get a new cheeseburger! The good thing is, they comped the whole meal without us even asking. Would I go back? Sure, If I was in the neighborhood, but this time, I'd stay indoors.
author: Greg H.

description: Been here twice.  Once to watch a Red Sox game.  Good atmosphere, full house.  Another time during the week to watch an NIT game and it was dead.  I'm giving it 4 stars based on the atmosphere for the sox game (if you're into that kind of thing).  The food is also pretty good;  I enjoyed my burger both times.  I think I had a burger the first time.I think they also have a little outdoor section, so if you don't want to watch anything that's also nice.  I'd come here if you lived in the area or wanted to watch Boston sports w/out cramming into that bar in Russian Hill.
author: Avi H.

description: Sometimes as I sit with my pint and basket of fries at the Yank I really think back to cold winters in Wisconsin at the bar on the river with the snow mobile parked outside and Hockey playing on the tv *sigh* nostalgia
author: Joy C.

description: Pretty good food, if a bit overpriced, and a good beer selection even if they often seem to be out of several things.  Some of the sandwiches are pretty good and they do have amazing fries.
author: Alured P.

description: Love the Red Sox paraphernalia.  Food is pretty good for a sports bar.  Wings were hot and a good blend of vinegar and spice.  Nachos were okay.  The gumbo was overpriced for what it was - mediocre.  Service was friendly.
author: Michelle C.

description: Nice hole-in-the-wall bar/restaurant where you can grab a beer and a sandwich.  Have some unique burgers/sandwiches - I had the Pee Wee Herman (pork) sandwich...haha...it's a Boston sports-themed bar.
author: Mich C.

description:
I came here for the Pats Raiders game this Sunday morning. The service was friendly and the crowd was OK - no one seemed very excited about the game except for my table - but the rest of the clientele put up with the rowdy behavior. The bloody mary was awesome. The veggie burger was ok (kinda pricy for $9) - garlic sauce was great. Nachos looked great and were a large portion (even the half size was huge). Food is definitely much better than bar quality.

Lots of street parking and the 22 stop is right outside.
author: Nors P.

description: Really good American style food.  Killer burgers, super good fries, good beers on tap.  Fun and unique shows on the weekends.  It's my favorite place to grab a beer and burger and watch the game in Potrero Hill.
author: Jeremiah R.

description:
This place is a f@#*king sh**thole. The service here is the worst in the city and it's evident that none of the servers give a damn. If you want watered down vodka tonics & have 2 hours to spare for a sub-par meal, then spend your hard earned cash at this spot. 

But if you care about timely service, decent drinks & a staff that makes an effort to get you your food, this is not the place for you. 

The scary thing is that even the folks who own this place could care less. Hey, at least take the time to clean the pissers in your crummy bar you a**holes!!!
author: Anon Y.

description:
Went here for the first time last Friday night with a group of friends - we arrived about 7:30 PM, and waiter was very quick to bring drinks and beers.  Unfortunately, the good service ended there.  We were all famished and quickly placed our food orders....fast forward to a half-hour later, and still no food.  Meanwhile, the waiter continues to come over to refill drink orders.  When queried about when our food would arrive, he shrugged and told us the kitchen was busy...humppp.  Finally, 3 rounds of beers later, the food arrives.  Appearance and taste told us that the food had been sitting under the heat lamps WAY too long - pulled pork sandwich was completely dried out.  Cole slaw had a hot crust, and french fries were stale. I took a few bites of the pork inside the crust, and pushed the rest away.  Only plus was that the manager needed our space for the band, and offered to comp us with free dessert or a drink.  The individual pecan pie was warm, and tasty, and the best part of the meal!  

The place has a nice ambience and feels like a neighborhood bar with many regulars....if they could only get their act together with the food.......
author: Debbie B.

description:
not being a local made me feel completely intimidated, and the "outsider" status that got written on my forehead when i walked in the door had a direct impact on the poor service i received.

not a good happy hour spot if you come from the corporate world - my attire had me sticking out like a sore thumb, and i was just wearing jeans & heels.

i probably won't be back, but try it out for yourself.
author: brittany z.

description: If you are coming just to hang in a dive bar and chill with some friends, this is a great place to hang out.  If you are hungry, eat before you arrive.  The food left something to be desired.  I ordered the special quiche and split pea soup.  The peas and carrots in the soup were still hard and it was pretty much water with floating veggies in it.  The quiche on the board said spinach and broccoli.  What I got was left overs from the day before and it didn't even contain anything green.  It had what tasted like canned cord, mushrooms and andoille sausage, smothered in cheddar cheese.  I'm sure it was good the day before, but it wasn't great as a left over, not to mention, not what I expected it to be - spinach and broccoli.
author: Megan S.

description: I've been five or six times over the past year and have finally thrown in the towel. Average food and rude, holier-than-thou service. Spend your time and money elsewhere!
author: Evan D.

description: Three stars are based on the decent food and the great service that you receive when you sit at the bar and eat.. Let me say that again.. "Sit at the bar and eat"..   Service in the dining area is a gamble they have a couple servers that will make your lunch miserable...
author: Kurt G.

description:
We came by this place last night after Father's Day dinner to have a few drinks and watch the end of the game.  There was no room at the bar so we stood around for a few minutes waiting to be seated, but all we got was "get out of the way" from a VERY rude female server!! When someone did finally ask us if we want a table, we were told that there was only outside seating available. Since there were no tv's out there, we decided to wait for a table inside while we watched the game. While we were waiting and being ignored by the bartender, my uncle asked the same rude waitress a question about the bar and she first ignored him completely as she was counting her tickets, then gave him a rude, brief answer without even looking up.
 We decided to take our business elsewhere. Why would anyone spend their money at this place????
author: Wish Z.

description:
Being from Boston, I thought this would be a great place to watch Game 5 of the Finals. That was a mistake. 

I first got there and except to see the entire place filled with diehard Boston fans.. that wasn't the case. This isn't the bar's fault, but just wanted to throw that out there.  In the main room, they have a bunch of TVs, but it didn't look like any were HD.. pretty poor for a Sports Bar.  I ended up watching the game in the back room, a better atmosphere because you can put the volume up as loud as you want, and it seemed like that's where more of the diehards were.  However, as previously mentioned, none of the TVs are HD, and the TVs in the backroom haven't been updated since the mid 90s.  I could barely see the score on one of them because of the terrible quality in picture. 

Besides the lack of good TVs at a sports bar (something that should be basic..) the wait staff was awful.  I sat down at a dirty table, and politely asked the waitress if she could possibly wipe the table down, and was responded with, "Oh, you want service?"  Umm.. yes, that is usually why I sit down at a table... They only had two waiters working that night, so ordering a burger and beer took about a half hour.  It was amazing to see they only had two people working on a night during the NBA finals in a bar that is decked out in New England gear...... And the burger was okay, nothing special.  A saving grace is that they do have a fair amount of beers on tap, and a good selection of bottled as well.. sooo, yeah. 

Overall, the lousy service and crappy tvs combine to make me not want to go back.
author: Nick L.

description:
Stopped by after the Anchor Brewery tour (2 blocks away). Decent pub grub, good service, friendly waitress, reasonable prices, outdoor seating. The cheesesteak sandwich was great with a pint of Anchor Liberty.

I'm not in this neighborhood often, but I'll stop by for a pint next time I'm around.
author: Barney L.

description:
I've got a love-hate relationship with this place. You can always catch a Red Sox or Pats game here, so if you're a fan of either team that's a good thing.

But the Yankee is a bit like one of those childhood friends whom you've stayed friends with out of laziness and habit and not because you still really like the person. In fact this friend can be really annoying and rude sometimes. But what the heck, he's got a big screen satellite TV that gets all the games, he's got really cool sports memorabilia on the walls that you like looking at (good thing, because that keeps you from getting really pissed off when your friend is rude or ignores you), he has a pretty good variety of beers, and he provides decent snacks for the games.

That's how I feel about the Connecticut Yankee. And clearly that's how they feel towards me. They just seem to tolerate me. Doesn't matter that I'm frequently there with a big group of people from Red Sox Nation spending A LOT of money on drinks and food. Or that whenever someone asks me where they should go to catch the game on TV that I always say, "Give the Yankee a try."  They don't care that the burger I ordered would probably be better if it was still hot when I receive it or that if they had brought me my beer when I asked for one 30 mins ago that I'd be ready to order another one now (thus putting more $ in their pockets). Nah. I'm an old friend. No need to go to any trouble to keep my friendship.

I used to think that I had one of those relationships with the Yankee where my regular patronage (and the fact that I got here regularly with a big group of local Sox fans) would translate into the Yankee wanting to keep me and my group coming back. I've tested this theory a few times now:

I tried to get them to put the sound on for the game the last time I was there.  Response: No.

I wanted to pull three tables together to accommodate the big group of us who were going to be there. (Contrary to Matt P's review, we did not take it upon ourselves to do it -- we actually asked permission, as we have every other time before that when we've been to the bar.) Response: a lot of exasperated breathing and eye rolling from one waitress, followed by some passive aggressive behavior -- making us wait a long, friggin' time for service.

Don't get me wrong. Every once in awhile I actually do have a pleasant time at the Yankee. But lately there are more bad times there than good.

I tried to reserve the back room for a recent group gathering. They told me that the room is first come first serve. And yet when we were there a couple weeks ago in the back room, they kicked us out because another group had "reserved" the room.  Apparently the Yankee is trying to make some new friends. Out with the old, in with the new. I'm going out and making some new friends of my own.
author: Jay Q.

description:
You gotta love the Yankee!

Whenever we are too tired to cook at home and want a nice relaxing environment and some great food, and even better tapped beers... we head down the street to the Yankee and grab a seat on the patio.

Here is the thing.  Don't be difficult when you go there.  Don't ask stupid questions or expect too much.  If you are laid back and calm the service there actually improves.  Think of it as going to a friend's house for dinner. We love it and feel like we are at home.  

Oh, and if you are one of those completely lame and fake hipsters who only sit on the patio to give yourself and everyone else around you lung cancer, while you chat about who the coolest indie band is while you relax from your hard day of serving lattes... please do not patron the Yankee... you ruin our relaxing dinner!
author: Kevin and Erin T.

description:
oh the yankee. wonderful times have been spent in the courtyard over cold beer, margaritas, the occasional cosmo, and the more occasional vodka tonic. a friendly bar with a neighborhood feel and some kick-ass appetizers. i could LIVE off the buffalo wings and cobb salad. that crucial fifth star, however is earned by the ambiance...perfect for getting together with a bunch of friends, a date, your family. it's a fine spot. (ooh, i second the fabulous comment on the glory of heat lamps...I must've been a reptile in a past life!)
ADDENDUM:
The occasional abnoxious fan can nearly ruin a pleasant dining experience. Luckily I had some buffalo wing bones as ammunition...just aimed at the team logo on the hat.
Oh, one more thing...and this definitely earns that fifth star...they are emphatic about wearing baseball hats forward - a sign in the back room reads something close to this "hats should be worn correctly or not at all"
author: Jessa B.

description: Love the Alcoholic Beverage License on the wall. It says "Eastern Arrogance Inc. Doing business as Conneticut Yankee". Don't know 'bout you but I just luuuuuv Massholes! Really, I do.
author: Jeff B.

description:
good selection of beer, they had hard pear cider...
they have food..
5 tvs to watch sports  

on a wednesday night they started rushing us out the door at 11pm, servers were not very nice
the servers were not very nice but i will give them one more chance

also the clouds were rolling in so fast, like witches were coming into town...good view with that
author: Kate R.

description: At the bottom of Potrero Hill sits this tavern filled with east coast sports nostalgia. Ideal pre-show chill spot when travelling to Bottom of the Hill or The Parkside. Only a few steps from those two houses of rock, at Connecticut Yankee you can avoid the crowd and the wait. An outdoor seating area with picnic bench seating is desirable and the heatlamps are key for the chilly bay area evenings. Full menus for brunch, lunch and dinner include a couple veggie options (veggie chili, veggie burger) but I can't comment because I've only ever eaten fries. The "live music" on the weekends are of the jam band variety (to be avoided, imho), but it won't be heard if you sit outside.
author: Alex D.

description: Perfect comfortfood.  Some say "bar food" but it is definately a step up from bar food.  Great beers and the atmosphere is classic east coast cozy local bar.  They make a good brunch, too and have an outdoor patio.  TV's need to be upgraded, but  I watch games there all the time.
author: David D.

description: Great place to catch a game if you are a fan of New England or Bay Area-based sports teams.  The food is above average pub food, but still that, pub food.  Their hot wings are good, lean with a damn tasty hot sauce.  I ordered the 'Wade Boggs', which is a chicken sandwich with cheese, lettuce, pickles, and tomato with fries. My girlfriend ordered the 'Fowl Play', a dish that is pretty much fried chicken with mashed potatoes and some greens.  I must say that I wish I could have traded.  I am a sucker for crunchy chicken.  The beer was fresh and cold, ( I had a Guinness from tap) with little head.  The bartender had no problem switching over the station on a t.v. closer to where we were sitting, so the viewing experience while eating was good.  I enjoyed the memorabilia-based decor being a Red Sox fan, so the atmosphere was great.  The "3" star decision could have been helped by our waitress, who we witnessed acting differently to all of her tables.  Why couldn't we be treated a little nicer?  I was born and  raised in NE, so I don't buy the "hard" personality concept one of the other reviewers mentioned.  Due to the nature of the bar (read baseball fandom), i will of course go back for the post-season fervor and neighborhood feel of the place.
author: TJ D.

description: Great neighborhood spot! Excellent beer selection and awesome bartenders--Steve is my fave! He's the nicest guy around, and if you're lucky, he might even tell you a joke or two!
author: Erin E.

description: service is crap but the crowd is a pissah when the Sox are on!
author: Minotaur N.

description: The food here is decent, the beer selection is good, and there's tons of seating in the main room. But does any of that really matter when you're watching Josh Beckett prove that he truly is the best pitcher in baseball? The answer is no. But I wouldn't recommend wearing any Yankees gear. Don't let the name fool ya, it's all about Boston in here.
author: Adrienne D.

description:
when I don't know where to go and want some comfort food, I go here.  a great SF pub.  good beer selection, very decent burger, generously portioned salads, pub food, real people, good vibe.  I've been going there for at least 10 years, mostly on weekend afternoons, sometimes midweek after work.  by and large the staff hasn't changed, that says something.  it's a great local's spot, stay away. :P  

it's in the boonies at the base of Potrero Hill but that makes parking dead simple.

beware of softball nights due to the fields a few blocks away, AFAIK the bands are mostly jam bands.  they do have a handful of TVs with sports.  there's a good jukebox, and the ambient music is always pleasing.

I love a comfortable spot to sit and have a beer with a good burger and fries, this place is ideal.  the outdoor patio is nicely shaded.  

it's in the boonies, but there's very easy parking.  the outdoor patio is great.

it's a pub with pub grub, that's all they do and they do it very well.
author: Mike G.

description: as the name suggests, this low-key somewhat out-of-the-way restaurant/bar pays homage to the east coast; various red sox paraphernalia and newspaper articles adorn the walls.  can't speak for the food as i only went to this place to see a friend's band - for a music venue, it's pretty basic - but there is ample room to move (should you be so inclined), the usual selection of bevvy's, and a great (heated) outdoor area.
author: Tamara S.

description: i like this place, good crowd, decent food, the atmosphere comes from the patrons.  could use a few spiff-ups, like the bathroom, but it is what it is and does it well.
author: e w.

description: Old Americana.... On-Tap beer, old wood bar and bar food.
author: Nancy F.

description: This is a regular meeting place for us and friends.  It's totally low key.  I've had several things there that were so so, but then I discovered their tuna melt and french fries.  They have great fries.  My husband and my friend's husband also say their Bloody Mary's are good.  I only have water, so I can't vouch for that.  Anyway, it's a good regular spot where you can kick back and just catch up with friends over yummy fries.
author: Claire P.

description: The outdoor patio is nice, but the service is sometimes grumpy inside and out. I've been here a dozen times or more. On my last visit I found RAW CHICKEN IN MY SALAD. My food was free, but my table still had to pay for thier burgers, which no-one enjoyed after the threat of food poisoning.
author: Cynthia s.

description: Solid pub food, nice outdoor seating, reasonable beer selection, friendly service. It's just kinda a no-brainer type of place - Expectations are clear, expectations are met. When in doubt, get yourself a sandwich and a beer, sit back and relax. It's that kinda place.
author: Matt B.

description: umm white trashy people where do you come from? why are you here? and in my face? please god bull doze this place and let these trashy people roam into the freeway...
author: f M.

description: Until recently, I thought I would continue to patronize the Yank due to it's fantastic atmosphere, great food and superb beer selection.  However, SOMETHING HAS DEFINITELY CHANGED SINCE JAN/FEB 2006.  Not only did the wait staff shrink to only a few regular guys (there used to be a good mix of male and female servers), but the guys that are there are absolutely the RUDEST and WORST people I have ever come across in the restaurant industry.  What would you do if you ordered something totally different than want was brought to you by the waiter only to have the waiter say, "well...SOMEONE ORDERED IT!!!", drop the food in the center of the table and walk away (and not even say "I am sorry" or attempt to bring something else)?  Or have the same waiter, on a totally different day, not bring an entree out at all and simply ignore your table all together (even after repeated requests for drinks and the entree in question)?  Or, have the barkeep, whom may also be the owner, tell you that they are "too busy for common courtesy"?  Well...I'll tell you what you'd do...you would find a new place to hang out and spend money (there are just too many other places in San Francisco to run a restaurant/bar like that).  Maybe someday, when the ownership changes, I'll go back, but until that day, I'll walk across the street to Park Side or up Connecticut to Goat Hill Pizza - which are both equally as good.
author: Justin L.

description: I met up with a group of friends here, we sat in back outside. Nice to be able to sit outside! I have to say though the waitress was terribly rude. I showed up later after my group of friends had already been there for a while. When the waitress came to take a round of orders, I ordered a Cosmo and she said "what kind of Vodka?" I said "what do you have?" She named them all...  I asked "what is your well?" She said "Absolute" I said "oooh, that sounds good, I'll have that"  She rolled her eyes at me  and said "if you can spare the dollar, you can have real vodka, Absolute is crap!" I was shocked! I looked at her in utter disbelief - I said "no, I'll just  have the absolute" She rolled her eyes again. I looked at my boyfriend who didn't hear the full exchange, I then looked at her and she said " if I was you, I'd splurge, spend the extra one dollar bill and have a real drink" I said something like.."Do, I have to order again?, I want it with Absolute" . This is when everyone at the table started to hear us. The waitress began taking more orders and then walked off. My boyfriend asked me why I was so rude to the waitress? I then had to explain to him the rest of the story and I was really pissed by this point!  I could not believe it! Not only was the waitress extremely rude and unprofessional, she caused a conflict between my boyfriend and I. She tried hard to make me feel cheap in front of a group of people - whom btw - I didn't even know very well. You can never know someones background. She didn't know that  I used to live in Sweden, when she said Absolute I immediately got nostalgic thinking about my friends there and the year I spent living in Hultsbruk.  I will never go here again! And I will most certainly tell this story to anyone thinking of going there, or who asks me if I've ever been there!
author: lydacious p.
